p: Mussismilia harttii is the main reef-building coral in northeastern Brazil [ 14], usually found at depths of 2–6 m, with isolated records up to 80 m [ 20]. It is a hermaphrodite spawner species, with an annual reproductive cycle, releasing its gametes between September and November new moons [ 21]. Currently, M. harttii shows the lowest percentages of coverage among its congeners [ 22] and populations in severe decline [ 19]. Although its conservation status at the IUCN (International Union for Conservation of Nature) database is still regarded as “Data Deficient” (DD). however the “Red Book of the Brazilian Endangered Fauna” (2014, 2018), already classifies the species as EN (Endangered) [ 19].
